subtitle: Thinking Allowed, conversations on the leading
edge of knowledge and discovery with psychologist
Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome. I'm Jeffrey Mishlove. Today's unusual topic is called The Message
of the Blue Apple. My guest is Ray Stanford, a
most unusual individual. Ray is the identical
twin brother of the distinguished parapsychologist
Rex Stanford. I've known Ray and Rex since 1974
when I invited both of them to speak together
at a symposium in Berkeley, California.
Ray has had an unusual career as a trance
channeler, as a psychic, as a distinguished UFO
researcher, and as a paleontologist. In fact, the Washington Post Sunday Magazine
ran a cover story about him called The Amazing
Dino Man because of all of his remarkable
paleontological discoveries. This interview about the Blue Apple will give us some
unique insights into Ray's life experience
and his character. He describes it as the most
precious incident of his life. This interview
was recorded in the Washington, D.C. area.
After Rex Stanford died last summer, I realized
that there would be a limited opportunity
for me to interview Ray. So, I made a special
trip to the Washington area to record his
reflections and memories. This will be the first
of a series of interviews recorded in his home.
I'll turn over to that video now. You were
telling me the story of the Blue Apple. Actually,
here I'm going to pan because it's right above you. Let me just let our viewers see.
The actual painting is right there. I'm going to zoom in on it for a moment.
Of course, I have an electronic copy, which will be even better. But here it is,
right in your living room. If I recall correctly,
the story begins sometime in the 1960s, one of
your very first experiences channeling you were in a meditation group at the time.
Yes. I believe that was in 1961. It was basically
a meditation group. I tell you the truth,
I don't remember after all these years exactly
how it began to work. We were getting so-called
psychic information from me. I'm not sure that
I expected it. I don't know if it was unexpected
either. But anyway, it was a group involving only
one, two, three, four people. That includes me.
One was a chiropractic doctor by the name of
Dr. Evelyn McGee. One was a chiropractic doctor
by the name of Brooks Limley. The third was a fellow that would shortly be getting his
chiropractic doctorate, William Gaston, Bill
Gaston, and myself, of course. Anyway, let me
say in preface that it is kind of odd to even be
talking about this here. I'm well known for my
research into things from the age of dinosaurs,
and I've had into logical work, but I'm also well
known for my attempt to end success in getting
instrumented recordings of UFOs. Of course,
these are fairly scientific orientations. But I was very young. I was born in 1938,
and here we were in 1961. I don't recall
exactly how old that makes me. 23, 24. Maybe so.
I was open-minded to psychic phenomena, because
my maternal grandmother had showed various signs
of being quite psychic, but she didn't make any
of it. She didn't even ever use the words I know.
But when you're saying grandmother's psychic,
it shows up in certain ways you learn about,
and so it did. So I accepted these things, but I wasn't really expecting anything
really highly significant to be happening in
this meditation group. But for some reason,
I began to, in this group, fall into an unconscious
state, and various things started being said to
me. My unconscious ultimately said that you're
hearing the unconscious erase Stanford tuned with
those areas of information or individuals with which it is directed by suggestion.
But there were other things, too. There were
voices that came to me that claimed to be
independent. Now, I'm very skeptical. I doubt
these were independent. I suspect they may have
come out of my own unconscious, conjuring something interesting to amuse the crowd,
so to speak, the crowd of three. But I don't
know. I really don't know why it was happening.
And not only that, there wasn't anything that really grabs my memory that happened
back then, except that they were curious and interested and would occasionally ask
my unconscious or whatever it was, if it could
tell them something about somebody or some
situation. But one night we decided to change
the location and have it out on a farm where
Bill Gaston lived, who was soon to become a
chiropractor. We decided for some reason to go
out there and have the meditation and see what
would come through, to use the term that we used
in that period. And in the midst of a so-called
reading, as they began to call them, something
came to that I'm not sure to this date whether
it was supposed to be my unconscious or it was
alleging to be some other type of independent being
or entity. But it made a statement that really
puzzled everybody. And when they told me afterward, I was equally or more puzzled.
You didn't even remember what took place.
I didn't even remember this stuff. And what happened is suddenly my voice,
that or whose every voice was allegedly
speaking through me, said something to effect.
By the way, it was referring to me, Ray Stanford, he will get the Blue Apple.
And I think Dr. McGee said, wait a minute,
what's this Blue Apple business? And this source,
my unconscious or whatever, said, why spoil the fun? Wait till it happens.
And they told me this afterwards. And I said,
oh, you know, it may be just a crock of baloney
that came through my unconscious. I mean, it doesn't make any sense. I don't know
what is a Blue Apple to start with. And so I
guess we left it at that. And that was, as I said,
I think that was in 1961. And eventually, I moved out to Phoenix. That, of course,
was down in Corpus Christi, Texas, right on the coast of Texas, where I was brought up.
But ultimately, for whatever reasons, I moved
out of Phoenix. I became known for giving these
psychic pronouncements and readings, in some
cases, for people physically to help their health.
And for other reasons, I don't remember all
of what we were getting. But I had completely
forgotten the Blue Apple business. But for some
reason, I had always been interested in art.
But for some reason, I happened to a gallery in
Scottsdale, Arizona, called the Gallery of Modern
Art, I believe. It was run by a very nice lady by
the name of Miro Bergson. And she was having a show
of an artist of whom I've never heard, Carlos
Merida. He was born in Guatemala. He was actually
Mayan blood descent. But he had moved to Mexico
City and was living in Mexico for quite some
time, and was rumored to be that most
handsome man. They used to say in Mexico City,
people have to judge that for themselves. But he was a wonderful, handsome man.
But I had never seen him at that point. They
had a photo on him showing a picture of him.
And they had some of his works. And I was able,
fortunately, to buy a small Merida painting.
And it was highly abstract. I have a picture of
it I can provide you. It was only about so big,
but it was called Los Emelos, which means the
twins. Now, I'm an identical twin. And so that
had a lot of appeal to me. But it was Mirota's
work. It was so unique and so different.
I was familiar with the social artist, Diego
Rivera, and others. And even some of the more
abstract ones. But I'd never heard of Carlos
Merida. But I loved his work immediately.
But that was it. So I bought this one and put it
on the wall. And then I heard an announcement that
excited me. It said in the mail I received an
announcement that in the Phoenix Art Museum,
they're having a huge show of Latin American art.
And I went and was enjoying the huge display. It
was sponsored by a group called the Friends of
Mexican Art there in Phoenix. And so I went into
one large room and was enjoying the works from
various paintings, various artists, I should say.
And then I walked into a still larger room. And
I'll never forget I came to the east door. And for
some reason, instead of just looking around at
an early wood, I compulsively turned around and
looked back where the door I'd come to. And to
the right of that door was a good-sized painting.
It's actually the one called the Blue Apple, the
larger of the two images in the photo behind me.
And I thought, gee, that is Carlos Merida.
Well, I love his work. What does he call this?
And I walked over and it said, La Poma Azul, in
parentheses, the Blue Apple. Oh my, what in the
Blue Apple? That's that name that came to
that reading in 1961. And this was in 1964. My
fascination that I had already built up with
Merida magnified immensely, what in the world,
why did he call this the Blue Apple? What does
it mean? And not only that, the reading said,
I'm going to get the Blue Apple. Well, everybody
was busy at the big opening that night.
But the next day I called the director of the
museum, who I had known before, and it was very
friendly. And I said, look, there's a painting
in the show that I'd like to buy. It's by Carlos
Merida, and it's called the Blue Apple. And can
you tell me how I'd buy that? He said, you can't.
I said, why not? And he said, because out of
all the Latin American paintings in the show,
the Friends of Mexican Art asked us to choose
the one we would like to have for the museum.
And I and the board of directors decided the
Blue Apple was the one we wanted. And oh boy,
I was really disappointed. And so on and so
forth. He said, well, you know, I've got an idea.
He said, maybe you should try to find out from the
gallery if there was a study for this painting.
And maybe that will satisfy your need for the
Blue Apple. And I said, well, I hope you're right.
I'll check. Well, I went down to the Scottsdale.
I live near, right on the edge of Scottsdale.
And I went to the gallery and spoke to Meryl
Bergson. And I said, look, I want to tell you a
strange story. I said, I wanted to buy the Blue
Apple. They called us Merida. I said, have you
seen it? And she said, yes, I've seen it. It was
a larger painting on what was called a polished
parchment. There was a panel of wood that was
hollow that was wooden warp. And he had adhered
a or his technicians had adhered a parchment
to it and he didn't paint it on the parchment.
And and then they put some type of acrylic or
clear plastic glaze over it so as to protect it.
And but I said, you know, I can't buy this thing.
That's the one they've chosen to be given by the
Prince of Mexican art. And I said so. And but
I was suggested that it was suggested I ask if
there was a study for it. She said, why are you so interested in the Blue Apple?
There are other Merida paintings available,
including right here at the gallery. And I said,
well, let me tell you something without going
into detail. Burn you with a lot of details.
I said, believe it or not, I was told in a
psychic reading, I didn't say it came to me.
But 1961, you know, that's nearly three,
maybe four years ago. And and out of the blue,
without explaining anything, the voice speaking
to me said, oh, by the way, he will get the Blue
Apple. And I said, I don't even know what this
means or why I should have it. But that that's
what happened. And I don't know why I'm even
supposed to have this thing. Because the one of
the chiropractors present asked us, asked my
voice, my unconscious or whatever this was,
please explain whether this is mysterious. And
it merely said, why spoil the fun? Wait till it
happens until I get the Blue Apple. But totally
surprised. And she said, he said, she said,
it's a real coincidence. I'm going to Mexico
City tomorrow. And I'm going to be seeing
Don Carlos Merida. Don is just a territory of
honor, a term of honor. And you say Don Carlos.
And but sees, I'll be seeing him. She said,
I'll ask him if he has the study for it still.
So she went to Mexico City. And when she got back,
she said, well, I have some some good news for
you. She said, I told Carlos Merida that and I
told him that that you were told this in a psychic
by a psychic. And that I don't know if she used the word reading or not, but
we're told this by a psychic. And he said, I must
tell you, that young man, he she told him I was
the young man in the 20s. That young man has had
a true revelation. And she said, well, I don't
matter. What is this? This happened in 1961. And
he says this young man has had a true revelation.
He said he must have the study for the Blue
Apple, but it's being shown right now in a show
at a gallery in Chaputtepec Park. But he said, I'm going to ask my chauffeur,
he was sitting right there, to go down and get it
and take it out of the show and take it down to
the gallery downtown to a senior in Essamore's
gallery and have her package it up to send to
you at your gallery where I have the address
and then you can give it to this young man.
And she said, wow, okay, fantastic. And so she, this is the story she's telling me.
And she still doesn't know why he said this young man has had a true revelation.
So years later, I get the year off the top of my head, but we have it in the catalog.
So the University of Texas decided to put on a big retrospective show called
A Salute to Carlos Merida, which thrilled me when I heard about it.
And so I went down to the museum and talked to the director and I said, look,
in this show, Carlos Merida, are you going to be having a painting
borrowed from the Phoenix Art Museum called the Blue Apple?
He said, indeed, we do. We're going to have that one in the show.
I said, would you like to have the study for it?
With Carlos Merida coming to town, I was delighted to have them say they wanted to
use the study of the Blue Apple along the side,
as you can see it here, the full size Blue Apple.
And the thing was, I didn't expect them, I brought it down and they photographed it.
I didn't expect them to, above all things,
you would think if they were going to feature
the Blue Apple, they'd put the finished painting
on the front of the catalog, Salute to Carlos
Merida in color. But no, they photographed and put
the study for the Blue Apple on the front of it,
which you can bet that drove me. And I mean, I was just kind of mind-boggled.
I had also talked to them. They said, well, you know, he has given this to you.
They didn't ask me for the details of why he
gave this to me, but they asked if I had a good
photograph of Carlos Merida. And as a matter of
fact, once this Blue Apple story had occurred,
a close friend of mine, a name of John Lucas there
in the Phoenix area, had become so fascinated by
this and that he would give this to me, he decided
to go to Mexico City, meet Carlos Merida, and ask
him, what the heck, why did he give it to him?
So he took a copy of a book that I had written.
This is your book about the Socorro.
About the Socorro UFO incident.
Yeah.
And he gave it to him, and he took a picture
of him holding it. So that's before I said,
you probably don't want to advertise my
book. They published it and trimmed that off,
but you can see my name at the bottom of the
book. But it's a very nice picture that John
Lucas got of Carlos Merida. So I was delighted
they included that. And once they said they wanted
me to write a picture, I said, well, maybe I could provide something else. I said,
do you have anything that gives any insight
into all these strange names of Carlos Merida's
paintings, like Shulu and Alivino? I said, the
truth of the matter is, he is a full-blooded
mind, and he has studied the sacred book of his ancient people, the Popawu. And I said,
that is where these names come from. But I've
studied it in depth, and I'd be happy to write
an article for the catalog on the themes and
titles of Carlos Merida's works. And he said,
we would be delighted because that's needed since so many of these have these weird
names in them. And so I wrote it, and it's in
the catalog. But he said, look, Ray, he said,
he said, I have been asked by the Martha Jackson Gallery, a most famous gallery,
top-level gallery in New York City, they're having
a show of Carlos Merida. And I've been asked to
come and give a talk on Carlos Merida because I
have the show here at the University of Texas.
He said, but I don't know anything about it.
He said, you know this man, and you know his
de facto Bible, the Mayan sacred book. He said,
if they accept this, would you be willing to tell?
I said, yeah, you bet I would. Well, he called
the director of the Martha Jackson Gallery,
and they said, yes, we've been delighted to have
him since he's the one that knows this stuff.
And we need to talk about Carlos Merida. So I
accepted it, and I flew up there and gave a talk.
And at the end of it, an elderly general who was quite a bit a lot older than me
came up. I was still a young man, as I said. And
he said, Mr. Stanford, he stuck out his hand and
shook my hand. He said, I wanted to thank you.
That is the most intriguing, interesting talk
on an artist or his work that I've ever heard
in my entire life. I said, well, thank you,
sir. I appreciate it. I had no idea who it was.
And he walked off. And the gallery came over and
tapped on the show, and he said, Mr. Stanford,
don't you know who that man was? And I said, no,
sir, I don't. He said, that was Alexander Calder, who made that compliment to you.
He's the man who invented mobiles. I said, oh,
my gosh. Wow. So that was well worth the while.
Just that. But you haven't told us yet why Carlos Merida said that this young man had
a true revelation. I hadn't gotten to it yet.
That is to say, at the University of Texas,
or when I was up there, I didn't know yet. Oh,
okay. You're giving it in chronological order.
I got back to Austin. Carlos Merida came for
the opening. They had printed the catalog and
everything was in order. And so not only did
Carlos Merida come, but his two daughters,
Ana and Alma, came with him. And the director of
the museum said, look, you're the guy that knows
this guy, de facto, though you've never met him. He said, would you be the one,
would you be in charge to take them anywhere
they want to go or where they need to go
and to be their host, so to speak. And I would be
delighted. So that happened. And so my wife and I
said, don't got us, how would you like to come
up to our apartment? We'd just like to visit and
talk about a few things. And he said, oh, sure,
we'd be delighted. And so he and his two daughters,
Alma and Ana came up there. And I said, look, I have a best identity. You gave me
that wonderful study for the Blue Apple. And
I said, and you said, that young man has had
a true revelation when he was told that I was
told this by a psychic. But why did you do that?
He said, this may sound a little crazy to you.
But he said, something happened in doing this
that I never had before in my life or since. And
here's what happened. He said, I was in my studio
and I was working on the study that I gave you,
Blue Apple, of course, before the big finished
painting. And he said, here's what happened.
He said, and I feel strange in telling you this
because these things don't happen to me, but they
did. He said, a presence, someone came into my
studio. It was like a presence here, it was like a
spiritual, it was a being. He said, I don't know.
He came into my studio and said that it must tell me that this had to be named
the Blue Apple. And it said, and here's what
you must do with this study, you must change it.
And if one looks at this study very carefully,
for the vertical blue pattern, you can see that
he then had already done something and it kind
of painted over it. And the president said,
you were to take a piece of paper and you'd cut
out three items. And one is the vertical thing
you see there. And one is down below, it looks
like a highly stylized head with a circle where
the mouth is open as a huge circle. And then
there's the one up, that you see up to the upper
right side, the actual blue circle up in the hand
being held up above. He said, it told me to cut
those out and paint them blue. And they must be
put right where it is said. And it must be called
the Palmaso, the Blue Apple. And he said, okay.
He said, Ray, let me tell you. He said, I'm an
artist. I paint my own paintings. Nobody comes in
and tells me how to paint a painting or the study
of the painting. He said, but it was not natural.
He said, it was supernatural. He said, I don't
understand it. How this happened. He said, my
people believe in supernatural phenomenon. My
Mayan ancestors. But he said, I'm not, I'm not
anything like this happened. He said, I don't know
what this is. But he said, when I heard that the
young man had been told by a psychic that he was
supposed to have the Blue Apple, I knew you had
to have this. And I sent quite immediately to be
picked up out of the ship and I signed it for
you. And so we sent it to you. He said, that's it.
And here's his daughter sitting here, this whole
story. Their mouths had just dropped open, you
know. My dad is telling us something weird that
we've never heard from him before. But it was
thrilling to me. But that was the outcome now.
But there was more to it. Carlos Merida, I went
down there and he said, you know, this, I was down
there at, if I'm immigrating, it was Christmas
time or they're up there abouts. Anyway, there
was a big party going on of some sort. I don't
remember if it was in Mexico City, of course.
And I was down there with my wife. So we're there
and Carlos Merida is there. And there was just a
big crowd and they had dancing, music and dancing
and so on and so forth. He said, Ray, I must
talk to you very seriously about something.
I said, what is it, Carlos? And he said, my wife's
nickname was Kitty or Kitty Bo. And he said,
you and Kitty must have children. And I said, well, we've never wanted children.
And he said, Ray, you must have children. Well, you're very serious. He walked out,
he came back and he said, he said, he said,
Ray, he said, you must take this dance with me.
Now, let me make it clear. He's not gay. It was not a gay thing. It was in Mexico City,
thank God, the kind of thing that doesn't
surprise you in Mexico City. And I said, well,
here he asked about it. The man called the
most famous, the most handsome man in Mexico,
one of the most esteemed artists to dance
with him. So I guess I'll dance with Carlos,
keep his old heart happy. And so we started
dancing around. And he said, again, Ray, he says,
Ray, you and Kitty must have children. And I
said, you know, as I said, we don't want children.
And he said, listen, he said, if you will have
children, I will be the godfather of your children.
Wow, wait a minute. That sounded like a pretty
good offer. And we danced around and I said,
he said, Ray, you must tell me that you and Kitty
will have children. I will be the godfather.
Didn't he also tell you, if I remember from your telling me the story earlier,
how important it is to have children? Yes, he
said, he said, it is very important. I don't
remember the details of what he told me, but he
did say that he stressed that and it sounded good.
This is what life is all about. Yes, I'm losing a lot of my memory at 84 and a half.
I remember you telling me the story. It was
so powerful. Yeah. And even when I told you,
I remember, I remember the power with which he
said it, that it is so important to life. And so
as a long story, so we had children. The first
was my daughter. And when she was about, I don't
know how, two and a half, I guess, I don't know,
we took her down there and he was just thrilled.
And you will be showing a nice photograph that I took of him. I believe he's kissing
my daughter, if I remember correctly. And he was
just so thrilled to have these godchildren and
see that. And eventually I had three children,
two sons. And my daughter is the oldest and I
wouldn't trade the world for them. And now I have
two grandchildren as well. And just the other day,
I called up my wonderful eldest son in Austin
and I said, do you realize that you wouldn't even
exist or your sisters or whatever my godchildren
are considered to them. None of you would exist
if it had not been for that one mysterious night
in a little farmhouse outside of Carper Christi
saying he will get the blue apple. And he said,
I know, Daddy, that's really something that's
really something to make you think about what life
is all about. When I think I would not have any
children or grandchildren if it were not for this
strange event and following through. But when I
get to thinking about it, it's not just a thing
like somebody's reading your mind and you get a
message and it's a good message. This is something
that was said in 1961 and across time, two years
later, or at least a one and a half years later,
Carlos Merida was painting what ended up being
called the blue apple, but not because he called
it that because the being that came in the room
and told him how to modify the study and told him
to call it that. And it's just, you know, it's
kind of mind-boggling to just contemplate this
whole thing happening. But here, two years later,
he does what this mysterious presence as he
told him to do and then four years later, when I
discovered the Phoenix Art Museum, I discovered
the blue apple and then asked if there was a study
for it and get it. I mean, here, we're stretching
a very strange psi event. I don't know how to
describe it, a psi event for over four years or
maybe three and a half years. And then, of course,
we're stretching it into children and grandchildren.
Well, there are different ways it could be
interpreted, but I'd be inclined to think that
it's not just a question of precognition. I think
your subconscious mind was in touch with a spiritual entity who had, one might say,
God's eye vision of the future. I feel that way
about it. To me, I mean, it's sacred to have this
thing and I should add more. I'm not against
psychic readings because I gave them for years.
But it's that people tend to believe everything.
And I don't think that's right. You don't want
to give up your own inner nature of feelings
if something is contrary to what you feel
inwardly. You must live according to your own heart, not according to some dictate
becomes a silver because they're giving a psychic
reading. And I suspect that in my own psychic
readings, although there are many people, I just
reread a letter in the email the other day from
somebody who said that I had saved the life of his
mother by giving a reading for her when she had
cancer and she was healed. But in other words, I
was really trying to do good and positive things,
but I believe that even to me, surely there
are probably places where my unconscious got
caught in with a lot of fiction I had been
believing or things. And so I want to caution
people this because this miraculous thing happened
with the Blue Apple. Don't go believing as if it
were gospel. Readings you read from books
published on Ray Stanford's readings. Let feel
for the good if you feel what is good there, but
reject that if there's parts of it that don't feel
like it's that it's right or commensurate with reality. We don't sacrifice our own
being and individuality for something because
it's merely uttered by a person that's in an
unconscious state or even in a conscious state.
We have to let our own heart find its measure
and to be comfortable with it. And so I think
that is the basic message of the Blue Apple is
let the spirit within you manifest itself and
blossom beyond the temple identity and your
emotionality and your sexuality and your whole
earthiness. Let it transform and show through you
and be lifted up, so to speak. So this is about
simply about transformation, letting the Apple,
the false identity become spiritualized to the
Blue Apple. Basically, I hope people can understand
the rather two terms I'm using, but I think that's
the message of the Blue Apple. And it's amazing
how that in a single event like that, one night
in a little old farmhouse, it was called the goat
house. We all had a big, big, huge male goat in
a pen out back in his farmhouse and we called it
the goat house. And this crazy, amazing statement,
he will get the Blue Apple, came out in that
situation. But did that particular voice ever
come through you again? Well, I don't know what
voice it was. All the recordings of these things,
they were eventually sold to somebody. My wife
knows who it was, but I think that person has died
too. And I have no idea how they would ever be
accessible even. But to me, it came through
my unconscious. I prefer to think that it was
some level of my own being in contact with attunement with a bigger, a larger reality.
And rather than some independent. And yet, on the other hand, a seemingly independent,
mysterious entity walked into Carlos Meredith's
studio and said, look, I'm going to tell you,
that's got to be named the Blue Apple and
you got to do it a certain way. Yeah. I mean,
you would think that there was some, some,
some kind of individual, individual duality,
spiritual individuality. Who was that? What was
it? I don't want to claim it was part of my psyche.
I don't think I'm that. Well, I like to think
that the whole universe is conscious. Well,
I like that. Yes. To me, yes. In other words,
